VLIB Function Reference

Hamming Distance

Introduction and Use Cases

Hamming Distance is a simple way to measure the similarity between two strings of equal length, by counting the number of corresponding bytes which are different. A lower Hamming Distance indicates that the two strings have a higher number of bytes which are the same in their offsets, than a pair of strings with a higher Hamming Distance.

In vision processing, Hamming Distance can be used to compare feature descriptors found from one frame to the next, to aid in a feature tracking algorithm.

Specification

Function

In an effort to club multiple passes of string comparisons in a single call for better performance, this function allows as input multiple pairs of strings for Hamming Distance computation, and produces an array of Hamming distance values, one value for each string pair.

The first dimension (length of each string) is an array of xSize bytes, while the second dimension (how many string pairs) is of ySize arrays. There are two modes.

  • Mode 0 - One-to-One i.e., pHammingDistance[i] = HammingDistance(pString1[i], pString2[i]); i = 0,1,2, ...ySize-1
  • Mode 1 - Many-to-One i.e., pHammingDistance[i] = HammingDistance(pString1[i], pString2[0]); i = 0,1,2, ...ySize-1

Inputs


    Parameter          Description
    -------------------------------------------------------------------
    pString1           Pointer to an array of byte arrays               (UQ8.0)
    pString2           Pointer to an array of byte arrays               (UQ8.0)
    xSize              Number of bytes in the first dimension           (UQ32.0)
    ySize              Number of rows (size of second dimension)        (UQ32.0)
    mode               0: one-to-one
                       1: many-to-one
    xPitch             Number of bytes between start of each string     (UQ32.0)
    pHammingDistance   Output array of hamming distances (size = ySize) (UQ32.0)

APIS

  • VLIB_hammingDistance
